text: Found the problem - took me a while to work it out ! you apply a logarithmic scaler with a function to the price field - price is what you’re trying to predict, and should not be scaled if you want to draw any meaningful conclusions with price later on (which is what I did with the MAE - remember i said this was how many dollars off the real price my model was. By scaling the price you put a maths barrier between yourselves and the real sale prices, so your MAE is now tiny, because its about the difference between scaled predictions and scaled actuals… ie, the proportion of error is the same, but the number is not easily relatable to $price, which should be left unscaled, ideally.

elements.text: Found the problem - took me a while to work it out ! you apply a logarithmic scaler with a function to the price field - price is what you’re trying to predict, and should not be scaled if you want to draw any meaningful conclusions with price later on (which is what I did with the MAE - remember i said this was how many dollars off the real price my model was. By scaling the price you put a maths barrier between yourselves and the real sale prices, so your MAE is now tiny, because its about the difference between scaled predictions and scaled actuals… ie, the proportion of error is the same, but the number is not easily relatable to $price, which should be left unscaled, ideally.

text: in essence, by rescaling you convert a figure like $350k to 12.34 and then the prediction is 11.6 - well in real life that might equate to $80K difference, but how to tell ? you would have to reverse the logarithmic scaler, before working out the MAE
